captions.text:
- If this were an
actress, who would it be?

- Yeah, there's no such
thing as an ugly person.
- For like the color, I like them spotty,

and for like it not
being so spotty like that
I like a nice soft banana.
- He threw it down in disgust,
declaring that it was not a good banana.
- You bite through it and you can
kind of feel your teeth breaking through

certain parts that are
really tough on the inside.
- This, I will tell you what,

- Yeah, look how fat
and short this one is.
- This one's clearly the organic banana.
I just am only picking things

based off of the opposite
of what you picked.

- I've already got
blackberry juice all over me.
- This is gonna ruin my Monday.
- It's gonna be so good, though.

- That's one of the best
blackberries I ever had.
- These are not as good, right?
- I found a bug in this one.
- I think this is the organic one
because the taste is much stronger.

- I think this one.
- [Right] I think this one.

- [Voiceover] And the
blue ones are organic.

- First impressions,
visually, these are bigger.

- But do they think we're
going to think that.
- Right, they think that we think

so that means that actually
this one's organic.
- I eat apples 'cause I'm supposed to,
but they're not my fruit of choice.

- I always assumed organic
apples were smaller.
I feel like it's been out in the sun.
- It looks bad, it's been cut poorly.

- I'd probably take one
bite and put it back,

like, at the refrigerator
in the morning time,
right before you brush your teeth, or pee.

- The texture is like
all, is like more powdery.

- I could see myself
eating this at the library.
- The moral of the story is that
the organic fruits taste the worst.

title: Organic Vs. Conventional Fruit: Can People Tell The Difference?

I think what a lot of people don't realize, is that organic foods go bad

comments.author: Bj Tibbs

comments.author: Ian Bartczak

comments.text:
If I'm not mistaken all bananas are genetically modified cause they are 
clones of a small group of bananas. Also many foods wouldn't be around if 
they weren't genetically modified due to pest and bugs or wouldn't even be 
edible. Genetic modification can also be a good thing since scientist 
isolate one gene in the plant and then put it into other plants to yield 
usually better results. Scientists isolated a gene in rice to make it more 
resilient to being waterlogged due to heavy rain and flooding. This helps 
many farmers in third world countries who otherwise would have crops only 
producing 40% out of a harvest.﻿
comments.author: Yoshi Rider

comments.text:
I can definately tell the difference between an organic banana and a 
conventional one. The conventional one is cosmetically prettier while the 
organic one taste way better and have seeds in it.

There are many varieties including ones with red skins (believe it or not). 
In my country they are called "guineos manzanos" and there are the smaller 
ones that look like short thick fingers (guineos niños) just to name a few 
which are normally sweeter.

I also can tell between an organic lemon and a conventional one. The 
organic one has seeds and take the grease out of your hands while the 
conventional one is seedless and if you squeeze the juice in your hands, it 
leave a funny kinda "greasy" feeling.﻿
comments.author: Maria Bardo

comments.author: Il Giallo

comments.text:
When I see something advertised as "100% organic" I usually think to myself 
"Oh really? I'm pretty sure there's quite a bit more than 0.5% water in 
there."

(For the less scientifically inclined, water is classified as non-organic 
in chemistry, and 0.5% because if it contained no more than 0.5% 
non-organic matter that would mean it's equal or more than 99.5% organic, 
which is rounded up to 100% when expressed in round percentages. Yay, 
science!)﻿

comments.text:
All bananas in the US are clonal for the most part and are technically an 
identical species. Also apples, Malus dometica all originate from Malus 
sieversii a wild apple species in china making all apples essentially 
inorganic because they are all GMO's technically through cross breeding 
with trees like crabapple, cherries, and more providing the multiple 
cultivars we have today.﻿

but it has nothing to do with it actually being organic.﻿

comments.author: thomas parisi

comments.text:
First of all, bananas are opened from the bottom because monkeys opened 
them that way,. and the monkeys are related to humans,so that makes it the 
way humans FIRST opened the bananas. And second of all people are now dumb 
because they can't tell the difference with ripe bananas and tart bananas. 
The ripe bananas have spots in them, and the spots are places where most of 
the natural sugar forms. Tart bananas are the only yellow ones and that 
taste the same, but the texture is different (Clumpy and not mushy like the 
ripe bananas) There is your fun fact for today! Jesus people you gotta 
learn your fruits!﻿
comments.author: Tasha Opsal

comments.text:
Organic simply means no pesticides were used. There is no where that is 
says it must be GMO-free to be labeled as organic. So most organic food is 
still GMO.﻿
comments.author: IceQueen975

comments.text:
Yeah, I can attest to organic apples being smaller and having a mealier 
texture. My grandparents had an old "wild" apple tree in their yard when I 
was a kid, and it produced the rankest little apples you ever saw... they 
were smaller than a tennis ball at full growth, green with tiny red 
splotches, were grainy, and tasted AWFUL. The tree itself was beautiful, 
but those apples would always be rotting in on the ground because none of 
us kids wanted to eat them. The cherries they had however, were beautiful 
Bing cherries and we would jump on the trampoline to pick them out of the 
trees and eat them until we couldn't eat anymore, they were awesome. 
Organic, non-cultivated fruits usually don't taste so great, especially 
when compared to the hybrid fruits we're used to, BECAUSE people 
specifically bred those fruits to taste better!﻿

comments.author: Cathy He

comments.text:
Whether or not people can tell the difference isn't the right thing to 
test. Rather, the thing they should be testing is health effects of both. 
The reason people are against GMO isn't so much because they don't like the 
idea of genetically modified plants so much as they know that pesticides 
are toxic and artificial growth hormones/ripening agents can have adverse 
affects. I hear that Oranges aren't always orange, sometimes they have to 
be artificially treated to get that color. People don't like that kind of 
deception, or having those chemicals it's treated with get into the food. 
By the way, pick a different text color so they don't blend in with the 
color of the table.﻿
